text: it's been a rough year for academic
institutions like the Johns Hopkins
University School of Medicine whose
research programs are like heavily on
federal grants Phil Cole who heads the
school's pharmacology Department it's
among the many research faculty who are
coping with the consequences of
across-the-board federal budget cuts
known as sequestration sequestration has
had a series of impacts on us these
include reduced numbers of brands coming
in and getting funded they also include
to exist in grants a reduction in funds
that has led to scaling back the broader
aims and goals of projects as well as a
reduction in staffing and students and
postdocs that can work on these projects
those students and postdocs are worried
to sequestration it creates almost a
sense of fear as far as what's going to
happen down the road well loss of these
these funds and these delays has kind of
lowered morale I think not to say that
our morale is low but that it has caused
us to be much more i think sensitive to
the sorts of things we can do to
consider the kinds of projects that
we're going to take on and to again to
sort of see our trainees struggle to
find positions of their own I've been
worried enough about lack of funding and
sequestration that I've considered
alternative career options
is it worth all the difficulties of
staying in science it would be easier to
change career to go into a non research
area of science the fact that we don't
really have a sense of how long these
cuts in funding are going to last is
another source of anxiety you you know
plan things like lab sighs and who to
recruit today based on what your funding
might be tomorrow and since that's so
uncertain it's it it really affects the
way you approach research in terms of
how we're managing as a department we're
more conservative we are not making
large expenditures on for example
instrumentation and renovations faculty
recruitment these things have been you
sort of brought to a much slower pace
while we watch and wait to see how this
is going to play out it's up to all of
us to to speak out and to to not be I
think strident or irrational but to sort
of carefully explain what this is doing
to to our faculty to our trainees and to
our research programs for chemical and
engineering news this is Andrea Widener
